item.title: Report: Microsoft is planning another round of major Xbox layoffs
item.content:encoded:
Microsoft is preparing to make even more Xbox workers redundant as part of a company-wide reorganization that will reportedly take place next week.

Bloomberg reports that managers within Xbox are expecting "substantial cuts" to be made across the division. Microsoft declined to comment when approached by the publication.

It's currently unclear how many people stand to be impacted by the purported cuts—or which studios and departments will be impacted. If the latest rumblings prove true, it would mark the fourth major round of layoffs within Xbox in the space of 18 months.

The U.S. tech company kicked off 2024 by laying off 1,900 people across its video game business following its colossal $68.7 billion merger with Activision Blizzard.

It followed those cuts by shuttering key studios such as Arkane Austin, Alpha Dog Games, and Tango Gameworks, the latter of which was eventually pulled back from the brink after being purchased by PUBG maker Krafton.

In May 2024, Xbox president Sarah Bond said those redundancies would ensure Xbox remained "healthy for the long term." It would be reasonable to suggest she spoke too soon.

Microsoft laid off another 650 video game workers in September 2024. Those cuts reportedly impacted staff across "corporate and supporting functions."

Related:Discord's 'social infrastructure' SDK helps devs capitalize on 'social play' trend

In an email sent to employees by Xbox boss Phil Spencer (obtained by Game File), workers were told the layoffs would help Microsoft deliver "long-term success."

Microsoft subsequently barrelled into 2025 by making another "small" round of layoffs in January, targeting what it called "underperforming" employees.

Game Developer has reached out to Microsoft for comment on the latest layoff reports.

item.title: Discord's 'social infrastructure' SDK helps devs capitalize on 'social play' trend
item.content:encoded:
Discord made a rather intriguing announcement back in March during the 2025 Game Developers Conference. On March 17 it announced a "social infrastructure and communications" SDK for the platform that lets developers use Discord as the social foundation for online games. The software does not require developers to force players to sign up for a Discord account, allowing creators to interface with communities that don't regularly use the popular chat application.

The announcement is likely inviting extra scrutiny from developers who are paying close attention to the company's planned IPO and an increasing number of lawsuits accusing the company of facilitating sexual abuse. But Discord's popularity with players of all stripes means developers can't ignore the potential of bringing players further into the fold. Will they go so far as to make it the main chat method for those games?

Co-founder and chief technology officer Stan Vishnevskiy thinks so. In an interview at GDC, he said the SDK came out of a "listening tour" with developers. The companies they spoke with described how they had plenty of resources on hand to make great games, but they lacked was experience building social systems.

"We're really great at the social components," he said. "We spent ten years building the technology and investing in it. [Now] how can we offer that to developers?"

Related:Discord's rumored IPO has us digging into its revenue strategy

That technology includes features such as "unified friends lists" that let players mix Discord and in-game friends lists, stronger game invitation mechanics, and "linked channels" that let players interact with Discord channels in-game instead of with the app. Communication through these channels will still be covered under the company's moderation tools and policies.

Discord's strength as a social platform is undeniable—and a critical one in an evolving landscape of "online social" play preferences in video games that go beyond classic multiplayer games. In the last few months developers have told us about about players wanting more avenues to hang out with their friends, not necessarily to compete against them. Even Nintendo seems to think the trend is picking up steam, with the Nintendo Switch 2 and the launch game Mario Kart World seemingly built to absorb players into its online walled garden.

Discord's garden isn't nearly as walled—but the SDK fits into an evolving strategy to blend Discord activity with everyday gameplay.

Discord integration is already driving MAUs

As a comparison metric for how game integration already provides returns, Sellis pointed to the "quests" system that might be floating in your Discord UI at this very moment. (Looking off to my second monitor, a large advertisement for Civilization VII -VR blocks some of my view of channels and servers.) Quests are, of course, a pricier advertising venue, and may not be right for all developers.

"Quests are driving players to play more," Sellis did say, calling it a strong "baseline metric" developers who've engaged with Quests have observed.

The history of Discord's quests does interact with a major part of the "online social" trend: the growing habit of players livestreaming games to their friends. It's a crucial way that even single-player games have become part of this trend. Sellis said developers they've spoken with are "curious" about rewarding players for this kind of activity, which doesn't fit neatly into existing community strategies like server management or purchased advertising.

Vishnevskiy pointed out that the first-ever quest Discord rolled out was a challenge to players to stream a game to their friends. That didn't necessarily make the act more popular—but one might see it as Discord recognizing its growing importance.

Sellis added that Discord has seen data indicating players who watch the games their friends stream are more likely to pick up a copy themselves—a modern day version of going over to your friend's house to watch them play Devil May Cry 3, then going home and buying your own copy (in my case, without your parents knowing).

If you're curious who's using the new Discord SDK, the company stated in its announcement that a range of companies from Tencent, to Splitgate 2 developer 1047 Games, to Supervive developer Theorycraft Games, to Saudi-owned Scopely are all among the first to start building social systems on top of it.

Theorycraft Games CEO Joe Tung made the biggest pitch for the tech, saying the company's use of Discord goes so far as relying on it for its fully-remote office. "Discord Social SDK is a valuable tool to make our social features like direct messaging, lobbies, and session invites absolutely seamless for Supervive players," he said.
